<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualizations: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, we see a distribution of Calories burnt on the x-axis along with their frequency and densities plotted.</li>
<li>The Distribution is clearly normal and multi-modal skewed towards the right, which can be understood as the practice runs while I was training for my first full Marathon in 2016 had the highest amount of calories burnt, with the marathon having more than 3000 calories burnt in a workout. </li>
<li>Also, the normal workout session involved around 400-500 calories, which has the highest count and am happy to see a lot of workouts also in the range of 1000 and above calories burnt.</li>
<li>Varying the binwidth also shows similar underlying distribution for the calories burnt.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> <em>b. Distribution of Calories Burnt across various Activities</em> </strong></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [57]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i running_data <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">900</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">480</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px

<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ggplot2"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"viridis"</span><span class="p">)</span>

g1 <span class="o"><-</span> ggplot<span class="p">(</span>running_data<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span>calories<span class="p">,</span> fill<span class="o">=</span>activityType<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    geom_density<span class="p">(</span>alpha<span class="o">=</span><span class="m">0.4</span><span class="p">,</span> adjust <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span> na.rm <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>   <span class="c1"># Overlay with transparent density plot</span>
    ylab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Density"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> scale_fill_viridis<span class="p">(</span>discrete<span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    xlab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Calories Burnt"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Calories Burnt overlayed with density estimate"</span><span class="p">)</span>
g1
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, we see a distribution of Calories Burnt on the x-axis along with the density of those activities on the y-axis for all the activity Types.</li>
<li>The Distributions are nearly normal or skewed towards the right, which is a nice observation and helps me understand the usual calories burnt doing a particular activity.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> <em>c. Outlier Analysis of Calories Burnt across various Activities</em> </strong></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [58]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i running_data <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">900</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">480</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px

<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ggplot2"</span><span class="p">)</span>

fill <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="s">"#4271AE"</span>
line <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="s">"#1F3552"</span>

ggplot<span class="p">(</span>running_data<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span><span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">),</span> y<span class="o">=</span>calories<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_boxplot<span class="p">(</span>fill <span class="o">=</span> fill<span class="p">,</span> colour <span class="o">=</span> line<span class="p">,</span> notch <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">,</span> width<span class="o">=</span><span class="m">0.2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    guides<span class="p">(</span>fill<span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">FALSE</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> coord_flip<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    theme<span class="p">(</span>axis.title.y<span class="o">=</span>element_blank<span class="p">(),</span>
        axis.text.y<span class="o">=</span>element_blank<span class="p">(),</span>
        axis.ticks.y<span class="o">=</span>element_blank<span class="p">())</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Distribution of Calories Burnt across all the activities"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> facet_wrap<span class="p">(</span> <span class="o">~</span> activityType<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, we want to analyze the outliers for each Activity Type of the total Calories Burnt.</li>
<li>The outliers in the right direction bring a smile to my face, as possibly those are the days I pushed myself and I don't want to comment on the outliers on the left side. The boxplots do help me understand the usual calories doing a particular activity clearly.</li>
<li>Some of the observations which are worth highlighting are as follows: <ul>
<li>Strength Training sessions had no outliers and had a maximum of around 1800 calories burnt in a session.</li>
<li>Treadmill Running, even though are small in number but usually for a session did lead to around 500 calores burnt.</li>
<li>Running had the outliers in the right directions, which are all the practice runs leading upto the Full Marathon as well as the full Marathon.</li>
<li>Cycling sessions were mostly around 30 minutes in length, duration of Citibike rental and led to about similar calories burn and vary within a small range without significant outliers.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Boxplots are an obvious choice to do outlier detection and uncover patterns about the underlying feature distributions.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section6"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="v.-Calories-Burnt-trend-for-all-the-activities-from-2012-17-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">v. Calories Burnt trend for all the activities from 2012-17 (Interactive D3.js visualization)<a class="anchor-link" href="#v.-Calories-Burnt-trend-for-all-the-activities-from-2012-17-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> The result for this visualization is also available at <a href="https://anujk3.github.io/edav-project/vis1.html">Visualization Link</a></strong> (Inspired by learning from the course <em>Storytelling with Data</em>) <a href="https://github.com/anujk3/edav-project/blob/master/vis1.html">Code</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'<iframe width="995" height="770" frameborder="0" src="http://anujkatiyal.com/edav-project/vis1.html" allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe>'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, we see all the activities plotted as separate bar plots in decreasing order of time range from 2017 to 2012.</li>
<li>The highest calories burnt can easily be seen for the events involving running, with around a 1000 calories burnt in every session.</li>
<li>Since moving to New York, that is the inital part of the plot, the focus has shifted from running to mostly strength training sessions and some Citibike rides because of yearly membership.</li>
<li>The fitness tracking journey started with mostly tracking the runs (rightmost part of the chart) and slowly with the improved fitness trackers bought with it, I started capturing more data about myself.</li>
<li>The reduced calories burnt in the recent times(inital part of the chart) can be owed to me facing sub zero temperatures for the first time(moving to NY from India) as well as the hectic schedule of graduate school.</li>
<li>All over, there is a nice trend of equally distributed strength training sessions, cardio sessions and running sessions that have been tracked through the years by me.</li>
<li>The challenge with the visualization was going back and working through <code>D3.js</code> and figuring out how to use the interactions. The interactions with the button and checkboxes have been included with this visualization.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section7"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="vi.-Hour-of-the-day-for-the-activities-and-how-it-has-changed-over-the-past-5-years-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">vi. Hour of the day for the activities and how it has changed over the past 5 years (Interactive D3.js visualization)<a class="anchor-link" href="#vi.-Hour-of-the-day-for-the-activities-and-how-it-has-changed-over-the-past-5-years-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> The result for this visualization is also available at <a href="https://anujk3.github.io/edav-project/vis2.html">Visualization Link</a></strong> (Inspired by learning from the course <em>Storytelling with Data</em>) <a href="https://github.com/anujk3/edav-project/blob/master/vis2.html">Code</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'<iframe width="995" height="910" frameborder="0" src="http://anujkatiyal.com/edav-project/vis2.html" allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe>'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, the activities have been plotted as a scatter plot in increasing order of time range from 2012 to 2017. The time range can be selected by moving the time range slider. The x-axis is just an increasing time scale that has been shown using the Date Range Slider. The y-axis shows the time of the day (0-24 hours) and the activities are plotted as points on the graph.</li>
<li>Most of the activity sessions for the past 5 years have been in the evening, which clearly show that I am not really a morning person. Specific activity sessions can be selected using their buttons and the date ranger can be moved to focus on the sessions done during that specific interval of time.</li>
<li>Most of the morning sessions mostly include running, which were the practice runs while training for marathons.</li>
<li>Since moving to New York, the rightmost part of the cumulative graph, I have mostly been doing the strength sessions late night at around 22:00 hour and some really late night cycle rides along the riverside.</li>
<li>The fitness tracking journey started with mostly tracking the runs (leftmost part of the chart) and slowly with the improved fitness trackers bought, I started capturing more data about myself. There is a decent distribution of data that has been captured in the last 5 years using various fitness trackers.</li>
<li>And looking at this visualization, I also realize that I have been missing the feel good factor after my long runs, and need to get back to running soon.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section8"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="vii.-Trend-:-Activity-minutes-per-month-for-years-2012-2016-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">vii. Trend : Activity minutes per month for years 2012-2016 (Interactive D3.js visualization)<a class="anchor-link" href="#vii.-Trend-:-Activity-minutes-per-month-for-years-2012-2016-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> The result for this visualization is also available at <a href="https://anujk3.github.io/edav-project/vis3.html">Visualization Link</a></strong> (Inspired by learning from the course <em>Storytelling with Data</em>) <a href="https://github.com/anujk3/edav-project/blob/master/vis3.html">Code</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [61]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">activity_mins_agg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"activityYear"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityMonth"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">activityMins</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"sum"</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">activity_mins_agg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"vis3.csv"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'<iframe width="995" height="720" frameborder="0" src="http://anujkatiyal.com/edav-project/vis3.html" allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe>'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, the total aggregated minutes of the activity types have been plotted on the y-axis with its variation across the months for the years 2012-2016.</li>
<li>The tracking for the workout sessions began in 2012, with about 200 minutes of activity captured during the month of October, but was still not much into tracking at that time.</li>
<li>During the year 2013, I started initially tracking my runs and most of the activity minutes for the months in 2013 are due to the runs that have been captured.</li>
<li>During the year 2014, I was still only capturing my runs for the year and had a decent running time during most of the months from March - May, which reduced because of excess heat during June and July and then the I started training for a half marathon, due to which the activity minutes picked up during the end of 2014.</li>
<li>During the year 2015, I just ran a half marathon for the month of January and after that the cool down period started. Because of the advanced fitness trackers bought during 2015, from June I started capturing my strength training sessions along with the running sessions and along with it, I started preparing for a half marathon in December and full marathon in January, because of which there has been a high value of activity minutes recorded for the last half of 2015 season.</li>
<li>For the year 2016, I was running regularly and also training regularly for my runs in the gym, because of which there has been such high activity recorded for the year 2016. I also ran my first full marathon in January 2016 and therefore have high activity recorded for the month of January 2016. The reduction in activity minutes as 2016 progressed can be aided to the joining of Graduate school in NY and recording mostly my strength training sessions.</li>
<li>Both straight connecting lines as well as the curve montonex were tried in D3.js, but using curved lines help better understand the trend rather than lines with sharp edges.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section9"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="viii.-Trend-:-Running-Mileage-(kms)-per-month-for-years-2014-2016-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">viii. Trend : Running Mileage (kms) per month for years 2014-2016 (Interactive D3.js visualization)<a class="anchor-link" href="#viii.-Trend-:-Running-Mileage-(kms)-per-month-for-years-2014-2016-(Interactive-D3.js-visualization)">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> The result for this visualization is also available at <a href="https://anujk3.github.io/edav-project/vis4.html">Visualization Link</a></strong> (Inspired by learning from the course <em>Storytelling with Data</em>) <a href="https://github.com/anujk3/edav-project/blob/master/vis4.html">Code</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [63]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">running_data_km</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[(</span><span class="n">running_data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"activityType"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"Running"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">|</span> \
                              <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">running_data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"activityType"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"Treadmill Running"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">running_data_kmagg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data_km</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"activityYear"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityMonth"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">actDistance</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"sum"</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">running_data_kmagg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"vis4.csv"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'<iframe width="995" height="720" frameborder="0" src="http://anujkatiyal.com/edav-project/vis4.html" allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe>'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the plot above, the running mileage has been plotted for every month of the years 2014-2016. I am only showing the data for these years as I was mostly capturing my running activities during these years.</li>
<li>For the year 2014, the running time has mostly varied with the running season in India. The running season starts around August and finishes with the Delhi Marathon and Mumbai Marathon in Decemeber and January respectively, showing higher kilometers run during those times of the year.</li>
<li>For the year 2015, after the Mumbai Marathon in January is when you rest and condition your body for the next running season. Even though in the previous plot I see that the recorded activity time is very high for the months in 2015, the actual running miles is less till the beginning of the running season in August-September. As I was preparing for my first full marathon in January 2016, the higher kilometer runs for the month of November and December 2015 are the due to the practice long runs for its preparation.</li>
<li>For the year 2016, the running kilometers are high for the year January when I was doing the practice runs and also ran my first full marathon. After that, I was just running about a long run once a week to keep conditioning along with the rest time after the season. In July-August, I was preparing to move to NY to join graduate school and during the initial months of moving to NY, I was still logging those kilometers due to the vicinity of Central Park near my house but as the semester proceeded and the workload increased along with extreme temperature, the running kilometers reduced significantly to even less than 10km during the previous years peak running months, i.e., November and Decemeber.</li>
<li>Curved lines help better understand the underlying trends as compared to connected lines with sharp edges.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section10"></a></p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="ix.-Total-minutes-spent-on-each-activity-type-during-the-months-in-year-2012-17">ix. Total minutes spent on each activity type during the months in year 2012-17<a class="anchor-link" href="#ix.-Total-minutes-spent-on-each-activity-type-during-the-months-in-year-2012-17">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [65]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">year_month_act_mins</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"activityYear"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityMonthName"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityType"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">activityMins</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"sum"</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">year_month_act_mins</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">inplace</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1">#year_month_act_mins</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [66]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i year_month_act_mins <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">980</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">1080</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px

<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ggplot2"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"viridis"</span><span class="p">)</span>

orderedclasses <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"January"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"February"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"March"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"April"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"May"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"June"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"July"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"August"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"September"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"October"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"November"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"December"</span><span class="p">)</span>
year_month_act_mins<span class="o">$</span>activityMonthName <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>year_month_act_mins<span class="o">$</span>activityMonthName<span class="p">,</span> levels <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">rev</span><span class="p">(</span>orderedclasses<span class="p">))</span>

g1 <span class="o"><-</span> ggplot<span class="p">(</span>year_month_act_mins<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span><span class="kp">sum</span><span class="p">,</span> y<span class="o">=</span>activityMonthName<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    geom_point<span class="p">(</span>aes<span class="p">(</span>color<span class="o">=</span>activityType<span class="p">,</span> shape <span class="o">=</span> activityType<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ylab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Months"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> scale_fill_viridis<span class="p">(</span>discrete<span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    xlab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Total Activity Minutes"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Total Minutes for Activity Types faceted by year and months "</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    facet_grid<span class="p">(</span>activityYear <span class="o">~</span> activityType<span class="p">)</span>
g1
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In a single cleveland dot plot, we can visualize the total activity minutes (x-axis) that I spent in the years 2012-2017 for the months.</li>
<li>From the visualization, it is clear that running has been the most tracked activity during all the years followed by strength training, which has been tracked frequently from 2015 end.</li>
<li>The activity minutes spent on an average during the activities are easily seen.</li>
<li>As I am using a facet grid for the visualization, it was difficult for me to reorder it based on the total activity minutes for specific months in every year, as fields are shown both on the x-axis as well as the y-axis.</li>
<li>The quality of data comes into question as I have mostly been doing a few activities in a year and shifting to other activities during another year. Even though this leads to large empty spaces in the visualization, if heatmap was used will always show up as empty blocks in those regions, which is why cleveland dot plots are better for such a visualizations with sparse entries.</li>
<li>While thinking about the visualization that would be able to uncover patterns for this analysis, I had the options to choose from heatmaps and cleveland dot plots, but for faceting the data based on various fields and showing patterns about a particular analysis, cleveland dot plots do work better.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section11"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="x.-Analyzing-average-calories-burnt-for-every-activity-type-during-the-months-of-years-2012-17">x. Analyzing average calories burnt for every activity type during the months of years 2012-17<a class="anchor-link" href="#x.-Analyzing-average-calories-burnt-for-every-activity-type-during-the-months-of-years-2012-17">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [67]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">year_month_cal_mins</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"activityYear"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityMonthName"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"activityType"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">calories</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s2">"mean"</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">year_month_cal_mins</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">inplace</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1">#year_month_cal_mins</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [68]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i year_month_cal_mins <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">980</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">1080</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px

<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ggplot2"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">require</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"viridis"</span><span class="p">)</span>

orderedclasses <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"January"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"February"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"March"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"April"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"May"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"June"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"July"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"August"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"September"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"October"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"November"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"December"</span><span class="p">)</span>
year_month_cal_mins<span class="o">$</span>activityMonthName <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>year_month_act_mins<span class="o">$</span>activityMonthName<span class="p">,</span> levels <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">rev</span><span class="p">(</span>orderedclasses<span class="p">))</span>

g1 <span class="o"><-</span> ggplot<span class="p">(</span>year_month_cal_mins<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span><span class="kp">mean</span><span class="p">,</span> y<span class="o">=</span>activityMonthName<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    geom_point<span class="p">(</span>aes<span class="p">(</span>color<span class="o">=</span>activityType<span class="p">,</span> shape <span class="o">=</span> activityType<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ylab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Months"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> scale_fill_viridis<span class="p">(</span>discrete<span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    xlab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Average Calories Burnt"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
    ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Average Calories burnt for Activity Types faceted by year and months "</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
    facet_grid<span class="p">(</span>activityYear <span class="o">~</span> activityType<span class="p">)</span>
g1
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In a single cleveland dot plot, we can visualize the average calories burnt (x-axis) during the years 2012-2017 for the months.</li>
<li>From the visualization, it is clear that running has been the most tracked activity during all the years followed by strength training, which has been tracked frequently from 2015 end. Also, number of calories burnt vary in the range of 500-700 for the running and strength training activities but vary a lot for my cardio sessions.</li>
<li>The average calories burnt are usually high for the running sessions and strength traning sessions as compared to cycling sessions or treadmill running sessions(because I don't run on the treadmill longer).</li>
<li>As I am using a facet grid for the visualization, it was difficult for me to reorder it based on the average calories burnt for specific months in every year, as fields are shown both on the x-axis as well as the y-axis.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><a id="section12"></a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="xi.-How-have-my-activity-levels-(based-on-average-Heart-Rate)-varied-along-the-chosen-aggregations?">xi. How have my activity levels (based on average Heart Rate) varied along the chosen aggregations?<a class="anchor-link" href="#xi.-How-have-my-activity-levels-(based-on-average-Heart-Rate)-varied-along-the-chosen-aggregations?">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> <em>a. Activity Levels and their variation along the aggregated days of the week</em> </strong></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [69]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">running_data_rec</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">running_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">running_data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"activityLevel"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">!=</span> <span class="s2">"Not Recorded"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">:]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [70]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i running_data_rec <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">980</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">680</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px


<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>vcd<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>RColorBrewer<span class="p">)</span>

mycolors <span class="o"><-</span> brewer_pal<span class="p">(</span>type <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"seq"</span><span class="p">)(</span><span class="m">4</span><span class="p">)</span>

orderedclasses <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Monday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Tuesday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Wednesday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Thursday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Friday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Saturday"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Sunday"</span><span class="p">)</span>
running_data_rec<span class="o">$</span>activityDayName <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>running_data_rec<span class="o">$</span>activityDayName<span class="p">,</span> levels <span class="o">=</span> orderedclasses<span class="p">)</span>

vcd<span class="o">::</span>mosaic<span class="p">(</span>activityLevel <span class="o">~</span> activityDayName<span class="p">,</span> data <span class="o">=</span> running_data_rec<span class="p">,</span> gp <span class="o">=</span> gpar<span class="p">(</span>fill <span class="o">=</span> mycolors<span class="p">),</span> direction <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"v"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"h"</span><span class="p">),</span>
            main <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Activity Levels and their variation along the aggregated days of the week"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_area">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the mosaic plot above, the activity levels have been categorized into Very Light, Light, Moderate, Hard and Very Hard. The categorization is done based on the average heart rate according to:<ul>
<li>Average HR < 114 : Very Light</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 114 and < 133) : Light</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 133 and < 152) : Moderate</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 152 and < 171) : Hard</li>
<li>Average HR >= 171 : Very Hard</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>According to the plot, Tuesdays and Sunday contribute to workout with hard activity levels, mainly the leg days in the gym on Tuesday and long running sessions on Sundays.</li>
<li>Most of the training sessions are Light for all the days, which owes to the strength training sessions where there are proper rest after a set of exercises.</li>
<li>Most of the workouts on Mondays are either Very Light or Light sessions, as it was a recovery day for the long runs done on Sundays. Similar can be said about Saturdays, which are mostly rest days or light activity days in preparation for the long run on Sundays.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> <em>b. Activity Levels and their variation along the aggregated activities</em> </strong></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [71]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span>R <span class="o">-</span>i running_data_rec <span class="o">-</span>w <span class="m">980</span> <span class="o">-</span>h <span class="m">680</span> <span class="o">-</span>u px


<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>vcd<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>RColorBrewer<span class="p">)</span>

mycolors <span class="o"><-</span> brewer_pal<span class="p">(</span>type <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"seq"</span><span class="p">)(</span><span class="m">4</span><span class="p">)</span>

orderedclasses <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Running"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Cycling"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Cardio"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Treadmill Running"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"Strength Training"</span><span class="p">)</span>
running_data_rec<span class="o">$</span>activityType <span class="o"><-</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>running_data_rec<span class="o">$</span>activityType<span class="p">,</span> levels <span class="o">=</span> orderedclasses<span class="p">)</span>

vcd<span class="o">::</span>mosaic<span class="p">(</span>activityLevel <span class="o">~</span> activityType<span class="p">,</span> data <span class="o">=</span> running_data_rec<span class="p">,</span> gp <span class="o">=</span> gpar<span class="p">(</span>fill <span class="o">=</span> mycolors<span class="p">),</span> direction <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"v"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"h"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">"v"</span><span class="p">),</span>
            main <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Activity Levels and their variation along the aggregated activities"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong> Analysis of the above visualization: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>In the mosaic plot above, the activity levels have been categorized into Very Light, Light, Moderate, Hard and Very Hard. The categorization is done based on the average heart rate according to:<ul>
<li>Average HR < 114 : Very Light</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 114 and < 133) : Light</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 133 and < 152) : Moderate</li>
<li>Average HR (>= 152 and < 171) : Hard</li>
<li>Average HR >= 171 : Very Hard</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>According to the plot, Running, Cycling and Treadmill Running are the activities where my activity level reach hard zone.</li>
<li>In none of the activities, the fitness tracker recorded very hard zones, which makes me happy.</li>
<li>In running and treadmill running, there are very few activities which are marked as Very Lights. Most of these activites do increase the heart rate faster.</li>
<li>Strength training sessions are usually marked as Light to Very Light owing the the fact that after every set, there is a rest period before another set and your heart rate keeps fluctuating.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="VI.-Conclusion">VI. Conclusion<a class="anchor-link" href="#VI.-Conclusion">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The main conclusions from the analysis of the data are as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>This analysis was made extra special as I was analyzing my captured data which helped me relive the past about my last 5 years.</li>
<li>The analysis actually helped me realize how much change in my lifestyle has happened from the time I joined graduate school. It just has been a huge change from more active to sedentary lifestyle, but the analysis does inspire me to be more fit and get more active.</li>
<li>Even though the analysis for the workouts here was limited by the ability of the fitness trackers used, I do realize that with the improvement in technology and my latest fitness tracker, I would be able to capture proper data about all my future activities and work on more quantified self projects like these.</li>
<li>One of the main limitations of this project also comes from the technical issues caused by Garmin by not providing an API to obtain all the data captured by the device. The issues becomes more clear as we cannot obtain our daily step data, which can be easily correlated with the activity times or heart rate to obtain better insights into which activities were predominant during an active day.</li>
<li>For the future, I hope Garmin makes it easier to obtain all the data captured by the advanced fitness trackers we are using now and we can do modeling and predictive analysis using the data. Also obtains patterns like which specific activity can help with the most calorie burn given a limited amount of time. Also, I will try and obtain some qualitative data about the mood associated with every workout and what sort of a role does that play in the analysis.</li>
<li>The lesson learnt can just be summarized as keep on the path of tracking workouts as any data captured can be put to good use by analyzing it. Also, since moving to NY in August 2016, I do realize that the running frequency has gone down and I need to put my running shoes back on. Also, I did realize while working on this project that how much important are these activity sessions for me and how are they so deeply linked to my happiness.</li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>
</div>
